A Multi-Token Coordinate Descent Method for Semi-Decentralized Vertical Federated Learning

Pedro Valdeira***Department of Electrical and Computer Engineering, Carnegie Mellon University; email: pvaldeira@cmu.edu. †††Institute for Systems and Robotics, Instituto Superior Técnico.
CMU, IST    Yuejie Chi∗
CMU    Cláudia Soares‡‡‡Department of Computer Science, NOVA School of Science and Technology.
NOVA    João Xavier†
IST
Abstract

Communication efficiency is a major challenge in federated learning (FL). In client-server schemes, the server constitutes a bottleneck, and while decentralized setups spread communications, they do not necessarily reduce them due to slower convergence. We propose Multi-Token Coordinate Descent (MTCD), a communication-efficient algorithm for semi-decentralized vertical federated learning, exploiting both client-server and client-client communications when each client holds a small subset of features. Our multi-token method can be seen as a parallel Markov chain (block) coordinate descent algorithm and it subsumes the client-server and decentralized setups as special cases. We obtain a convergence rate of 𝒪​(1/T)𝒪1𝑇\mathcal{O}(1/T) for nonconvex objectives when tokens roam over disjoint subsets of clients and for convex objectives when they roam over possibly overlapping subsets. Numerical results show that MTCD improves the state-of-the-art communication efficiency and allows for a tunable amount of parallel communications.

44footnotetext: A preliminary version of this work was presented at the 2022 NeurIPS Workshop on Federated Learning: Recent Advances and New Challenges (Valdeira et al., 2022).

1 Introduction

Federated Learning (FL) is a machine learning paradigm where data is distributed across a set of clients who collaborate to learn a model without sharing local data (McMahan et al., 2017). Most FL literature considers data distributed by samples (horizontal FL), where each client holds all the features of a subset of the samples, yet recently there has been a growing interest on feature-distributed setups (vertical FL), where each client holds a subset of the features for all samples (He et al., 2018, Chen et al., 2020, Alghunaim et al., 2021, Liu et al., 2022b, Castiglia et al., 2022). Vertical FL may be of particular interest for applications using, for example, time series data measured by personal devices to learn a model of some cross-client phenomenon of interest (e.g. meteorological), where each sample corresponds to the data collected across the devices at a given timestamp. Another example involves performing a computer vision task using multiple views of the same object, where a sample corresponds to the concatenation of views from different devices.

FL often deals with the client-server setup, where a server is connected to all clients and the clients do not communicate with each other, forming a star-shaped topology. However, such schemes have a single point of failure and suffer from a communication bottleneck on the server (Lian et al., 2017). On the other hand, there is extensive literature on decentralized optimization, where there is no server—from earlier work motivated by applications such as wireless sensor networks and multiagent control (Nedic and Ozdaglar, 2009, Duchi et al., 2012, Qu and Li, 2018), to recent work motivated by FL (Koloskova et al., 2020, Li et al., 2020, Zhao et al., 2022). Yet, these algorithms often converge slowly in sparse and large networks (Nedic et al., 2018) and, although they spread the communication load across the network, they tend to have poor communication efficiency. Semi-Decentralized FL (SDFL) uses both client-server and client-client communications, reducing the overhead at the server (Lin et al., 2021) while avoiding the shortcomings of decentralized setups and being able to handle multiple clusters of clients.

When concerned with the communications between clients, the use of a token method (Bertsekas, 1997, Nedic and Bertsekas, 2001, Ram et al., 2009, Johansson et al., 2010, Mao et al., 2020, Hendrikx, 2022), where a model-embedding token follows a random walk over a communication graph (undergoing local updates), allows for better communication efficiency (Hendrikx, 2022) than the more common consensus-based methods (Nedic and Ozdaglar, 2009, Duchi et al., 2012, Qu and Li, 2018, Koloskova et al., 2020). Yet, the convergence rate of token methods degrades even faster for larger and sparser networks, due to a lack of parallel communications (Hendrikx, 2022). Based on the idea that performing multiple random walks in parallel leads to a linear speed-up in the cover time (Alon et al., 2008), multi-token methods (Ye et al., 2020, Chen et al., 2022, Hendrikx, 2022) mitigate this problem by running multiple tokens simultaneously and combining them.

1.1 Our contribution

Motivated by the above observations, we propose an SDFL multi-token algorithm for vertical FL. Our main contributions are as follows.

  • •

    We introduce Multi-Token Coordinate Descent (MTCD), which, to the best of our knowledge, is the first multi-token method leveraging the SDFL scheme to achieve a flexible degree of dependence on the server, recovering both client-server and fully decentralized FL as special cases;

  • •

    We show that MTCD converges at a rate of 𝒪​(1/T)𝒪1𝑇\mathcal{O}(1/T) for nonconvex objectives when tokens roam over disjoint subsets of clients and for convex objectives when they roam over possibly overlapping subsets of clients;

  • •

    Numerical experiments on both synthetic and real data and for a variety of communication setups show that MTCD improves the state-of-the-art communication efficiency.

1.2 Related works

Coordinate descent.

Coordinate Descent (CD) methods (Wright, 2015), where (blocks of) coordinates are updated sequentially, rather than simultaneously, are natural candidates for optimization in feature-distributed learning. The block selection is most often cyclic (Beck and Tetruashvili, 2013) or independent and identically distributed at random (Nesterov, 2012, Richtárik and Takáč, 2012). In contrast, Sun et al. (2019) considers block selection following a Markov chain. Several extensions to CD have been proposed, such as acceleration and parallelization (Fercoq and Richtárik, 2015) and distributed CD methods (Liu et al., 2022b, Chen et al., 2022).

Vertical FL.

Existing vertical FL works include He et al. (2018), which generalizes Smith et al. (2018) to the decentralized setting. Both works use primal-dual optimization techniques, as does DCPA (Alghunaim et al., 2021), a state-of-the-art decentralized method. In contrast, the following methods work in the primal domain, allowing them to learn more general models. In (Chen et al., 2020), a CD-based method is used, but no local updates are performed, while Liu et al. (2022b) does consider local updates. This latter work and Castiglia et al. (2022), which introduces the use of compressed embeddings, lowering the communication cost, are particularly close to our method. Note that the communication costs in vertical FL methods typically depend on the number of samples (or batch size, in the case of stochastic methods) (Alghunaim et al., 2021, Liu et al., 2022b, Castiglia et al., 2022), further highlighting the importance of communication efficiency. An interesting line of work related to vertical FL is hybrid FL (Zhang et al., 2021b), which deals with datasets distributed both by samples and features. For a more detailed survey of vertical FL methods, see (Wei et al., 2022, Liu et al., 2022a).

Semi-Decentralized FL.

Recently, SDFL approaches have been proposed to lower communication costs and deal with data heterogeneity (Lin et al., 2021, Guo et al., 2021), and to handle intermittent connections, latency, and stragglers (Bian and Xu, 2022, Yemini et al., 2022). Additionally, other SDFL works deal with (multi-layered) hierarchical networks (Zhang et al., 2021a, Hosseinalipour et al., 2022). SDFL is also referred to as hybrid FL sometimes, but we opt for the term semi-decentralized FL to avoid confusion with the data partitioning setting mentioned above.

2 Problem setup

We consider a dataset 𝑿∈ℝN×d𝑿superscriptℝ𝑁𝑑\bm{X}\in\mathbb{R}^{N\times d} with N𝑁N d𝑑d-dimensional samples distributed by features across a set of clients [K]≔{1,…,K}≔delimited-[]𝐾1…𝐾[K]\coloneqq\{1,\dots,K\}. Client k𝑘k holds its local data 𝑿k∈ℝN×dksubscript𝑿𝑘superscriptℝ𝑁subscript𝑑𝑘\bm{X}_{k}\in\mathbb{R}^{N\times d_{k}} and we have 𝑿=[𝑿1,⋯,𝑿K]𝑿subscript𝑿1⋯subscript𝑿𝐾\bm{X}=[\bm{X}_{1},\cdots,\bm{X}_{K}]. Note that d1+⋯+dK=dsubscript𝑑1⋯subscript𝑑𝐾𝑑d_{1}+\dots+d_{K}=d. We consider a broad class of machine learning models, know as split neural networks (Ceballos et al., 2020), illustrated in Figure 1.

In split neural networks, each client has an associated local model hk​(⋅;𝑿k):𝚯k↦ℋk:subscriptℎ𝑘⋅subscript𝑿𝑘maps-tosubscript𝚯𝑘subscriptℋ𝑘h_{k}(\cdot\,;\bm{X}_{k})\colon\bm{\Theta}_{k}\mapsto\mathcal{H}_{k} parameterized by 𝜽k∈𝚯ksubscript𝜽𝑘subscript𝚯𝑘\bm{\theta}_{k}\in\bm{\Theta}_{k}, which extracts a (typically lower-dimensional) representation of 𝑿ksubscript𝑿𝑘\bm{X}_{k}. For simplicity, we write hk​(𝜽k)≔hk​(𝜽k;𝑿k)≔subscriptℎ𝑘subscript𝜽𝑘subscriptℎ𝑘subscript𝜽𝑘subscript𝑿𝑘h_{k}(\bm{\theta}_{k})\coloneqq h_{k}(\bm{\theta}_{k};\bm{X}_{k}). These embeddings, hk​(𝜽k)subscriptℎ𝑘subscript𝜽𝑘h_{k}(\bm{\theta}_{k}), are then combined using an aggregation mechanism H:ℋ1×⋯×ℋK↦ℋ:𝐻maps-tosubscriptℋ1⋯subscriptℋ𝐾ℋH\colon\mathcal{H}_{1}\times\dots\times\mathcal{H}_{K}\mapsto\mathcal{H} to form H​(h1​(𝜽1),…,hK​(𝜽K))𝐻subscriptℎ1subscript𝜽1…subscriptℎ𝐾subscript𝜽𝐾H(h_{1}(\bm{\theta}_{1}),\dots,h_{K}(\bm{\theta}_{K})), which is used as input to a fusion model ϕ:ℋ×𝚯0↦ℝ:italic-ϕmaps-toℋsubscript𝚯0ℝ\phi\colon\mathcal{H}\times\bm{\Theta}_{0}\mapsto\mathbb{R}, parameterized by 𝜽0subscript𝜽0\bm{\theta}_{0}. Although more aggregation mechanisms are possible (Ceballos et al., 2020), we focus on aggregation by concatenation (the most general case) and by sum. While 𝜽k∈𝚯ksubscript𝜽𝑘subscript𝚯𝑘\bm{\theta}_{k}\in\bm{\Theta}_{k} is associated with 𝑿ksubscript𝑿𝑘\bm{X}_{k}, acting as a local model for client k𝑘k, our fusion model 𝜽0subscript𝜽0\bm{\theta}_{0} can be learned at different locations, depending on whether we consider the existence of a server. Split neural networks include, for example, generalized linear models, such as linear regression, logistic regression, and support vector machines, where hk​(𝜽k)=𝑿k​𝜽ksubscriptℎ𝑘subscript𝜽𝑘subscript𝑿𝑘subscript𝜽𝑘h_{k}(\bm{\theta}_{k})=\bm{X}_{k}\bm{\theta}_{k} for k∈[K]𝑘delimited-[]𝐾k\in[K] and 𝚯0subscript𝚯0\bm{\Theta}_{0} is an empty set.

Let 𝚯𝚯\bm{\Theta} denote a parameter space such that 𝚯=𝚯0×𝚯1×⋯×𝚯K𝚯subscript𝚯0subscript𝚯1⋯subscript𝚯𝐾\bm{\Theta}=\bm{\Theta}_{0}\times\bm{\Theta}_{1}\times\dots\times\bm{\Theta}_{K} and f:𝚯↦ℝ:𝑓maps-to𝚯ℝf\colon\bm{\Theta}\mapsto\mathbb{R} denote our objective function, our goal is to solve the following optimization problem, which encompasses the training of split neural networks:

min𝜽∈𝚯⁡{f​(𝜽)≔ϕ​(H​(h1​(𝜽1;𝑿1),…,hK​(𝜽K;𝑿K)),𝜽0)},subscript𝜽𝚯≔𝑓𝜽italic-ϕ𝐻subscriptℎ1subscript𝜽1subscript𝑿1…subscriptℎ𝐾subscript𝜽𝐾subscript𝑿𝐾subscript𝜽0\min_{\bm{\theta}\in\bm{\Theta}}\;\left\{f(\bm{\theta})\coloneqq\phi\left(H\big{(}h_{1}(\bm{\theta}_{1};\bm{X}_{1}),\dots,h_{K}(\bm{\theta}_{K};\bm{X}_{K})\big{)},\,\bm{\theta}_{0}\right)\right\}, (1)

where the labels 𝒚𝒚\bm{y} are included in the loss function, which we assume to be known by all clients.

Throughout the paper, we consider Problem (1) and assume f𝑓f is an L𝐿L-smooth function. The standard definition of L𝐿L-smoothness is given below. We define and assume f⋆≔min𝜽⁡f​(𝜽)>−∞≔superscript𝑓⋆subscript𝜽𝑓𝜽f^{\star}\coloneqq\min_{\bm{\theta}}f(\bm{\theta})>-\infty.

Assumption 1 (Smoothness).

A differentiable function f:ℝd↦ℝ:𝑓maps-tosuperscriptℝ𝑑ℝf\colon\mathbb{R}^{d}\mapsto\mathbb{R} is L𝐿L-smooth if there exists some L∈(0,∞)𝐿0L\in(0,\infty):

∥∇f​(𝒙)−∇f​(𝒚)∥≤L​∥𝒙−𝒚∥,∀𝒙,𝒚∈ℝd.formulae-sequencedelimited-∥∥∇𝑓𝒙∇𝑓𝒚𝐿delimited-∥∥𝒙𝒚for-all𝒙𝒚superscriptℝ𝑑\lVert\nabla f(\bm{x})-\nabla f(\bm{y})\rVert\leq L\lVert\bm{x}-\bm{y}\rVert,\quad\forall\;\bm{x},\bm{y}\in\mathbb{R}^{d}. (A1)

3 Proposed method

3.1 The fully decentralized setting

We start by introducing a simple, special case of our algorithm, which we refer to as Single-Token Coordinate Descent (STCD). This method, which is also a subroutine of our general algorithm, is closely related to Sun et al. (2019) and the application mentioned therein, taken from Mao et al. (2020). Yet, we work in the primal domain and on a feature-distributed setting.

Setup.

In this section, we do not require the existence of a server. We solve Problem (1) in a fully decentralized manner, communicating through channels described by a communication graph 𝒢=(𝒱,ℰ)𝒢𝒱ℰ\mathcal{G}=(\mathcal{V},\mathcal{E}), where 𝒱≔[K]≔𝒱delimited-[]𝐾\mathcal{V}\coloneqq[K] is the vertex set and ℰℰ\mathcal{E} the edge set. We denote the set of neighbors of client k𝑘k by 𝒩k≔{i:{i,k}∈ℰ}≔subscript𝒩𝑘conditional-set𝑖𝑖𝑘ℰ\mathcal{N}_{k}\coloneqq\{i\colon\{i,k\}\in\mathcal{E}\} and define 𝒩¯k≔𝒩k∪{k}≔subscript¯𝒩𝑘subscript𝒩𝑘𝑘\bar{\mathcal{N}}_{k}\coloneqq\mathcal{N}_{k}\cup\{k\}. In this section only, 𝜽0subscript𝜽0\bm{\theta}_{0} is associated with some client k𝑘k, which is responsible for updating both the local model it holds, 𝜽ksubscript𝜽𝑘\bm{\theta}_{k}, and the fusion model 𝜽0subscript𝜽0\bm{\theta}_{0}.444We do this for alignment with the analysis in Sun et al. (2019), where all blocks are selected following a Markov Chain. However, in practice, we may want to update 𝜽0subscript𝜽0\bm{\theta}_{0} at each client instead, in which case the analysis would need to be adjusted.

Token.

Since all clients know ϕitalic-ϕ\phi, if a client knows 𝒵≔{H​(h1​(𝜽1),…,hK​(𝜽K)),𝜽0}≔𝒵𝐻subscriptℎ1subscript𝜽1…subscriptℎ𝐾subscript𝜽𝐾subscript𝜽0\mathcal{Z}\coloneqq\{H(h_{1}(\bm{\theta}_{1}),\dots,h_{K}(\bm{\theta}_{K})),\bm{\theta}_{0}\}, it can compute f𝑓f. We call 𝒵𝒵\mathcal{Z} our token. The size of the token depends on the model being considered. For example, if ℋk⊆ℝN​Esubscriptℋ𝑘superscriptℝ𝑁𝐸\mathcal{H}_{k}\subseteq\mathbb{R}^{NE} for all k𝑘k (i.e., we have an E𝐸E-dimensional embedding per sample) and we do aggregation by concatenation, then 𝒵𝒵\mathcal{Z} is of size K​N​E+dim(𝚯0)𝐾𝑁𝐸dimensionsubscript𝚯0KNE+\dim(\bm{\Theta}_{0}), where dim(⋅)dimension⋅\dim(\cdot) denotes the dimensionality of a space. Yet, for aggregation by sum, we drop the dependency on K𝐾K. In particular, for generalized linear models, 𝒵={𝑿​𝜽}𝒵𝑿𝜽\mathcal{Z}=\{\bm{X}\bm{\theta}\} is of size N𝑁N.

The token suffices to perform local CD steps.

We have seen that a client holding 𝒵𝒵\mathcal{Z} can compute f𝑓f. Yet, more importantly, if client k𝑘k has access to its local data 𝑿ksubscript𝑿𝑘\bm{X}_{k} and local model 𝜽ksubscript𝜽𝑘\bm{\theta}_{k}, then holding 𝒵𝒵\mathcal{Z} enables it to compute the partial gradient with respect to 𝜽ksubscript𝜽𝑘\bm{\theta}_{k},

∇kf​(𝜽)≔∇𝜽kf​(𝜽)≔subscript∇𝑘𝑓𝜽subscript∇subscript𝜽𝑘𝑓𝜽\displaystyle\nabla_{k}f(\bm{\theta})\coloneqq\nabla_{\bm{\theta}_{k}}f(\bm{\theta}) =∇𝜽kϕ​(H​(h1​(𝜽1),…,hK​(𝜽K)),𝜽0)absentsubscript∇subscript𝜽𝑘italic-ϕ𝐻subscriptℎ1subscript𝜽1…subscriptℎ𝐾subscript𝜽𝐾subscript𝜽0\displaystyle=\nabla_{\bm{\theta}_{k}}\phi\left(H(h_{1}(\bm{\theta}_{1}),\dots,h_{K}(\bm{\theta}_{K})),\bm{\theta}_{0}\right)
=d​ϕ​(H​(h1​(𝜽1),…,hK​(𝜽K)),𝜽0)d​H​(h1​(𝜽1),…,hK​(𝜽K))⋅d​H​(h1​(𝜽1),…,hK​(𝜽K))d​hk​(𝜽k)⋅d​hk​(𝜽k)d​𝜽k,absent⋅𝑑italic-ϕ𝐻subscriptℎ1subscript𝜽1…subscriptℎ𝐾subscript𝜽𝐾subscript𝜽0𝑑𝐻subscriptℎ1subscript𝜽1…subscriptℎ𝐾subscript𝜽𝐾𝑑𝐻subscriptℎ1subscript𝜽1…subscriptℎ𝐾subscript𝜽𝐾𝑑subscriptℎ𝑘subscript𝜽𝑘𝑑subscriptℎ𝑘subscript𝜽𝑘𝑑subscript𝜽𝑘\displaystyle=\frac{d\phi\left(H(h_{1}(\bm{\theta}_{1}),\dots,h_{K}(\bm{\theta}_{K})),\bm{\theta}_{0}\right)}{dH(h_{1}(\bm{\theta}_{1}),\dots,h_{K}(\bm{\theta}_{K}))}\cdot\frac{dH(h_{1}(\bm{\theta}_{1}),\dots,h_{K}(\bm{\theta}_{K}))}{dh_{k}(\bm{\theta}_{k})}\cdot\frac{dh_{k}(\bm{\theta}_{k})}{d\bm{\theta}_{k}},

where 𝒵𝒵\mathcal{Z} is used in the computation of the first two terms. This will allow client k𝑘k to update its local model 𝜽ksubscript𝜽𝑘\bm{\theta}_{k}.

We now describe STCD, summarized in Algorithm 1, where 𝒰𝒰\mathcal{U} denotes the uniform distribution. We index 𝜽𝜽\bm{\theta} and 𝒵𝒵\mathcal{Z} with two counters: one for the sequence of clients (and thus coordinate block) visited while roaming and one for the local updates at each client. To simplify the description of the algorithm, we omit 𝜽0subscript𝜽0\bm{\theta}_{0} for the rest of Section 3.1, as if it were part of the local model of the client it is associated with for updating purposes. Yet, 𝜽ksubscript𝜽𝑘\bm{\theta}_{k} does not leave k𝑘k but 𝜽0subscript𝜽0\bm{\theta}_{0} does, as 𝜽0subscript𝜽0\bm{\theta}_{0} is part of the token.

    Initialization: The token 𝒵s,qsuperscript𝒵𝑠𝑞\mathcal{Z}^{s,q} must always be in accordance with 𝜽s,qsuperscript𝜽𝑠𝑞\bm{\theta}^{s,q}. So, as 𝒵0,0superscript𝒵00\mathcal{Z}^{0,0} starts at client k0superscript𝑘0k^{0}, this client must know {H​(h1​(𝜽10,0),…,hK​(𝜽K0,0)),𝜽00,0}𝐻subscriptℎ1subscriptsuperscript𝜽001…subscriptℎ𝐾subscriptsuperscript𝜽00𝐾subscriptsuperscript𝜽000\{H(h_{1}(\bm{\theta}^{0,0}_{1}),\dots,h_{K}(\bm{\theta}^{0,0}_{K})),\bm{\theta}^{0,0}_{0}\}. For some models, we can achieve this by initializing the local models 𝜽k0,0subscriptsuperscript𝜽00𝑘\bm{\theta}^{0,0}_{k} such that the embeddings hk​(𝜽k0,0)subscriptℎ𝑘subscriptsuperscript𝜽00𝑘h_{k}(\bm{\theta}^{0,0}_{k}) are independent of local data 𝑿ksubscript𝑿𝑘\bm{X}_{k}. When this is not possible, the clients can send their initial embeddings to k0superscript𝑘0k^{0} as a prelude.

    Updating the local model and the token: as explained above, the client holding the token after s𝑠s hops, kssuperscript𝑘𝑠k^{s}, can compute the partial gradient with respect to its local model 𝜽kssubscript𝜽superscript𝑘𝑠\bm{\theta}_{k^{s}} locally. This allows it to perform a CD step. Further, to lower communication costs, we do Q𝑄Q local CD updates at each client. That is, for q=0,…,Q−1𝑞0…𝑄1q=0,\dots,Q-1:

    and 𝜽ks,q+1=𝜽ks,qsuperscriptsubscript𝜽𝑘𝑠𝑞1superscriptsubscript𝜽𝑘𝑠𝑞\bm{\theta}_{k}^{s,q+1}=\bm{\theta}_{k}^{s,q} for k≠ks𝑘superscript𝑘𝑠k\not=k^{s}. We must now update 𝒵𝒵\mathcal{Z} accordingly. To compute 𝒵s,q+1superscript𝒵𝑠𝑞1\mathcal{Z}^{s,q+1}, we use 𝒵s,qsuperscript𝒵𝑠𝑞\mathcal{Z}^{s,q}, hks​(𝜽kss,q+1)subscriptℎsuperscript𝑘𝑠superscriptsubscript𝜽superscript𝑘𝑠𝑠𝑞1h_{k^{s}}(\bm{\theta}_{k^{s}}^{s,q+1}), and hks​(𝜽kss,q)subscriptℎsuperscript𝑘𝑠superscriptsubscript𝜽superscript𝑘𝑠𝑠𝑞h_{k^{s}}(\bm{\theta}_{k^{s}}^{s,q}), which are held by kssuperscript𝑘𝑠k^{s}. For example, for aggregation by sum, we have

    H​(h1​(𝜽1s,q+1),…,hK​(𝜽Ks,q+1))=H​(h1​(𝜽1s,q),…,hK​(𝜽Ks,q))+hks​(𝜽kss,q+1)−hks​(𝜽kss,q).𝐻subscriptℎ1subscriptsuperscript𝜽𝑠𝑞11…subscriptℎ𝐾subscriptsuperscript𝜽𝑠𝑞1𝐾𝐻subscriptℎ1subscriptsuperscript𝜽𝑠𝑞1…subscriptℎ𝐾subscriptsuperscript𝜽𝑠𝑞𝐾subscriptℎsuperscript𝑘𝑠subscriptsuperscript𝜽𝑠𝑞1superscript𝑘𝑠subscriptℎsuperscript𝑘𝑠subscriptsuperscript𝜽𝑠𝑞superscript𝑘𝑠H(h_{1}(\bm{\theta}^{s,q+1}_{1}),\dots,h_{K}(\bm{\theta}^{s,q+1}_{K}))=H(h_{1}(\bm{\theta}^{s,q}_{1}),\dots,h_{K}(\bm{\theta}^{s,q}_{K}))+h_{k^{s}}(\bm{\theta}^{s,q+1}_{k^{s}})-h_{k^{s}}(\bm{\theta}^{s,q}_{k^{s}}).

    This allows us to perform multiple local CD steps. Further, after these Q𝑄Q steps, the updated token can be sent to client ks+1superscript𝑘𝑠1k^{s+1}. Thus, by induction, we keep the token up-to-date throughout our algorithm.

  • •

    Communicating the token: the token is communicated to a neighbor of kssuperscript𝑘𝑠k^{s}. This results in a sequence of clients (and blocks) that follows a Markov Chain.

In essence, STCD is a technique allowing for Markov Chain Coordinate Descent (Sun et al., 2019) to be performed in feature-distributed setups. In terms of the progress made in the parameter space, Algorithm 1 differs from Sun et al. (2019) only in that we consider local updates with Q>1𝑄1Q>1.

Convergence guarantees.

If f𝑓f is an L𝐿L-smooth function (A1) with a nonempty set of minimizers and (𝜽i)i=1rsubscriptsuperscriptsuperscript𝜽𝑖𝑟𝑖1(\bm{\theta}^{i})^{r}_{i=1} is a sequence generated by Algorithm 1, Sun et al. (2019) give convergence guarantees for Q=1𝑄1Q=1. In particular, let r=s​Q+q𝑟𝑠𝑄𝑞r=sQ+q, we have under mild assumptions on the Markov chain (for example, if the Markov chain is time-homogeneous, irreducible, and aperiodic) that limr→∞𝔼​∥∇f​(𝜽r)∥=0subscript→𝑟𝔼delimited-∥∥∇𝑓superscript𝜽𝑟0\lim_{r\to\infty}\mathbb{E}\lVert\nabla f(\bm{\theta}^{r})\rVert=0 and, let Δ≔f​(𝜽0)−f⋆≔Δ𝑓superscript𝜽0superscript𝑓⋆\Delta\coloneqq f\left(\bm{\theta}^{0}\right)-f^{\star},

𝔼[mini∈[r]∥∇f(𝜽i)∥2]≤(Ω1​(τ−1)2+Ω2)​Δr,\mathbb{E}\left[\min_{i\in[r]}\lVert\nabla f(\bm{\theta}^{i})\rVert^{2}\right]\leq\frac{(\Omega_{1}(\tau-1)^{2}+\Omega_{2})\Delta}{r}, (3)

where Ω1subscriptΩ1\Omega_{1} and Ω2subscriptΩ2\Omega_{2} are constants that depend on the minimum value of the stationary distribution of the Markov chain πminsubscript𝜋\pi_{\min}, the step-size η𝜂\eta, and the smoothness constant L𝐿L. Further, τ𝜏\tau denotes the πmin2subscript𝜋2\frac{\pi_{\min}}{2}-mixing time of the the Markov chain. (We present all the aforementioned Markov chain-related terms in Appendix A.) While Sun et al. (2019) only consider Q=1𝑄1Q=1 explicitly, their analysis can also cover the Q>1𝑄1Q>1 case. To see this, consider a virtual dynamic graph 𝒢r=(𝒱,ℰr)superscript𝒢𝑟𝒱superscriptℰ𝑟\mathcal{G}^{r}=(\mathcal{V},\mathcal{E}^{r}) where 𝒱𝒱\mathcal{V} is the original vertex set and, recalling that ℰℰ\mathcal{E} is the original edge set,

ℰr={ℰif ​r​ mod ​Q=0,{{i,i}:i∈𝒱}otherwise.superscriptℰ𝑟casesℰif 𝑟 mod 𝑄0conditional-set𝑖𝑖𝑖𝒱otherwise\mathcal{E}^{r}=\begin{cases}\mathcal{E}\quad&\text{if }r\text{ mod }Q=0,\\ \{\{i,i\}:i\in\mathcal{V}\}&\text{otherwise}.\end{cases}

Running STCD on 𝒢rsuperscript𝒢𝑟\mathcal{G}^{r} with a single local update is equivalent to running STCD on the original graph 𝒢𝒢\mathcal{G} with Q𝑄Q local updates. This dynamic graph preserves the properties required for the analysis to hold. To see this, let 𝑷𝑷\bm{P} denote the transition matrix of a random walk on the original graph 𝒢𝒢\mathcal{G} and let 𝑷​(r)𝑷𝑟\bm{P}(r) denote the transition matrix of a random walk on 𝒢rsuperscript𝒢𝑟\mathcal{G}^{r}. Note that 𝑷​(r)=𝑰𝑷𝑟𝑰\bm{P}(r)=\bm{I} for all rmodQ≠0modulo𝑟𝑄0r\mod Q\not=0, where 𝑰𝑰\bm{I} denotes the identity matrix, and 𝑷​(r)=𝑷𝑷𝑟𝑷\bm{P}(r)=\bm{P} for all rmodQ=0modulo𝑟𝑄0r\mod Q=0. Assuming, for simplicity, that R≥Q𝑅𝑄R\geq Q, we have that 𝑷​(r)​𝑷​(r+1)​…​𝑷​(r+R)=𝑷⌊R/Q⌋𝑷𝑟𝑷𝑟1…𝑷𝑟𝑅superscript𝑷𝑅𝑄\bm{P}(r)\bm{P}(r+1)\dots\bm{P}(r+R)=\bm{P}^{\lfloor R/Q\rfloor}. We thus recover the results in Sun et al. (2019) up to a factor of Q𝑄Q in the mixing time. (That is, in (3), we replace τ𝜏\tau by Q​τ𝑄𝜏Q\tau.)

Limitations.

The decentralized token algorithm in this section has an appealing simplicity. However, while it outperforms state-of-the-art feature-distributed learning algorithms in a variety of setups, as we will see in Section 4, its performance deteriorates faster with network connectivity than these decentralized consensus-based algorithms and its convergence per iteration can be rather slow. These problems will be mitigated by the more general multi-token method presented next.

3.2 Semi-decentralized setting

In Section 3.1, we introduced a special case of MTCD where a single token roams over a fully decentralized set of clients. We now present our method in the semi-decentralized setting, which subsumes the setting in Section 3.1 as a special case. Multi-token CD alternates between a roaming step and a syncing step.

  • •

    Roaming. We start with multiple, matching tokens at a subset of the clients. As each token performs a different random walk realization, they undergo different sequences of CD updates, becoming distinct.

  • •

    Syncing. To leverage these parallel computations while keeping our model estimates coupled, we periodically sync the roaming tokens at the server, combining the progress of multiple CD sequences.

By alternating between these two steps, we get a communication-efficient algorithm with a flexible degree of parallelization, depending on the number of tokens and the frequency at which we sync them. This allows us to smoothly control the trade off between the communication efficiency of settings with less parallel computations and the faster iteration convergence of settings with more parallel computations.

We further generalize STCD by allowing the use of stochastic gradient estimates. Let 𝑩∈ℝB×d𝑩superscriptℝ𝐵𝑑\bm{B}\in\mathbb{R}^{B\times d} denote a mini-batch of size B𝐵B defined by a random set of indices ℬ⊆[N]ℬdelimited-[]𝑁\mathcal{B}\subseteq[N], we make the following standard assumptions that our gradient estimate is unbiased and has a bounded variance. For clarity, we make the dependency on 𝑿𝑿\bm{X} explicit by writing ∇f​(𝜽;𝑿)=∇f​(𝜽)∇𝑓𝜽𝑿∇𝑓𝜽\nabla f(\bm{\theta};\bm{X})=\nabla f(\bm{\theta}).

Assumption 2 (Unbiased gradients).

For any mini-batch 𝐁𝐁\bm{B}, the stochastic gradient is unbiased:

𝔼ℬ​[∇f​(𝜽;𝑩)]=∇f​(𝜽;𝑿),∀𝜽∈ℝd.formulae-sequencesubscript𝔼ℬdelimited-[]∇𝑓𝜽𝑩∇𝑓𝜽𝑿for-all𝜽superscriptℝ𝑑\mathbb{E}_{\mathcal{B}}[\nabla f(\bm{\theta};\bm{B})]=\nabla f(\bm{\theta};\bm{X}),\quad\forall\;\bm{\theta}\in\mathbb{R}^{d}. (A2)
Assumption 3 (Bounded variance).

For any mini-batch 𝐁𝐁\bm{B}, there exists a constant σ≥0𝜎0\sigma\geq 0 such that:

𝔼ℬ​∥∇f​(𝜽;𝑩)−∇f​(𝜽;𝑿)∥2≤σ2B,∀𝜽∈ℝd.formulae-sequencesubscript𝔼ℬsuperscriptdelimited-∥∥∇𝑓𝜽𝑩∇𝑓𝜽𝑿2superscript𝜎2𝐵for-all𝜽superscriptℝ𝑑\mathbb{E}_{\mathcal{B}}\lVert\nabla f(\bm{\theta};\bm{B})-\nabla f(\bm{\theta};\bm{X})\rVert^{2}\leq\frac{\sigma^{2}}{B},\quad\forall\;\bm{\theta}\in\mathbb{R}^{d}. (A3)

Setup.

In addition to a communication graph 𝒢=(𝒱,ℰ)𝒢𝒱ℰ\mathcal{G}=(\mathcal{V},\mathcal{E}), we now also consider the existence of a central server with links to all clients, as illustrated in Figure 2. The existence of a server brings a change to the model partitioning: 𝜽0subscript𝜽0\bm{\theta}_{0} is now updated at the server. Further, we now have ΓΓ\Gamma tokens roaming simultaneously. Each token 𝒵γsubscript𝒵𝛾\mathcal{Z}_{\gamma} has an associated model estimate 𝜽​(γ)𝜽𝛾\bm{\theta}(\gamma), for γ∈[Γ]𝛾delimited-[]Γ\gamma\in[\Gamma]. Thus, during the roaming step, each client k𝑘k must now keep up to ΓΓ\Gamma local model estimates 𝜽k​(γ)subscript𝜽𝑘𝛾\bm{\theta}_{k}(\gamma) in memory.555In practice, it suffices to to add a copy of 𝜽tsuperscript𝜽𝑡\bm{\theta}^{t} as a new token visits during a given roaming step (with a maximum of ΓΓ\Gamma model estimates at a client), resetting the number of copies when syncing. To simplify the description of the algorithm, we define [Γ]0≔[Γ]∪{0}≔subscriptdelimited-[]Γ0delimited-[]Γ0[\Gamma]_{0}\coloneqq[\Gamma]\cup\{0\}, with token γ=0𝛾0\gamma=0 staying at the server throughout the roaming step.

We now describe MTCD, summarized in Algorithm 2, where kγt,ssuperscriptsubscript𝑘𝛾𝑡𝑠k_{\gamma}^{t,s} denotes the client holding token γ𝛾\gamma after t𝑡t synchronizations and s𝑠s hops and Pγsubscript𝑃𝛾P_{\gamma} denotes a distribution over the clients, for γ∈[Γ]𝛾delimited-[]Γ\gamma\in[\Gamma]. We index 𝜽𝜽\bm{\theta} and 𝒵𝒵\mathcal{Z} with three counters: one for synchronizations at the server and two matching the counters used in STCD. For simplicity, we write 𝒵t≔𝒵1t,0,0=⋯=𝒵Γt,0,0≔superscript𝒵𝑡subscriptsuperscript𝒵𝑡001⋯subscriptsuperscript𝒵𝑡00Γ\mathcal{Z}^{t}\coloneqq\mathcal{Z}^{t,0,0}_{1}=\dots=\mathcal{Z}^{t,0,0}_{\Gamma} and 𝜽t≔𝜽t,0,0​(1)=⋯=𝜽t,0,0​(Γ)≔superscript𝜽𝑡superscript𝜽𝑡001⋯superscript𝜽𝑡00Γ\bm{\theta}^{t}\coloneqq\bm{\theta}^{t,0,0}(1)=\dots=\bm{\theta}^{t,0,0}(\Gamma).

  • •

    Initialization: all model-token pairs (𝜽​(γ),𝒵γ)𝜽𝛾subscript𝒵𝛾(\bm{\theta}(\gamma),\mathcal{Z}_{\gamma}) are initialized to the same values. As in STCD, 𝒵γsubscript𝒵𝛾\mathcal{Z}_{\gamma} must be in accordance with 𝜽​(γ)𝜽𝛾\bm{\theta}(\gamma).

  • •

    Roaming: The server samples a set of indices ℬtsuperscriptℬ𝑡\mathcal{B}^{t} and communicates it to each client k𝑘k, which returns its local embedding hk​(𝜽kt;𝑩t)subscriptℎ𝑘subscriptsuperscript𝜽𝑡𝑘superscript𝑩𝑡h_{k}(\bm{\theta}^{t}_{k};\bm{B}^{t}). This allows the server to compute token 𝒵tsuperscript𝒵𝑡\mathcal{Z}^{t} and send copies of it to start the roaming step at kγt,0∼Pγsimilar-tosubscriptsuperscript𝑘𝑡0𝛾subscript𝑃𝛾k^{t,0}_{\gamma}\sim P_{\gamma}, where Pγ​(k)≔ℙ​(kγt,0=k)≔subscript𝑃𝛾𝑘ℙsubscriptsuperscript𝑘𝑡0𝛾𝑘P_{\gamma}(k)\coloneqq\mathbb{P}(k^{t,0}_{\gamma}=k). Note that P0subscript𝑃0P_{0} is a point mass distribution with support over the server, k=0𝑘0k=0 (a node without neighbors). As 𝒵γsubscript𝒵𝛾\mathcal{Z}_{\gamma} reaches client kγt,ssubscriptsuperscript𝑘𝑡𝑠𝛾k^{t,s}_{\gamma}, it is used to perform a local CD step on model estimate 𝜽​(γ)𝜽𝛾\bm{\theta}(\gamma) with respect to block kγt,ssubscriptsuperscript𝑘𝑡𝑠𝛾k^{t,s}_{\gamma} and is then updated accordingly. Each 𝒵γsubscript𝒵𝛾\mathcal{Z}_{\gamma} roams for S𝑆S hops, as in STCD. In parallel, 𝜽0​(0)subscript𝜽00\bm{\theta}_{0}(0) is updated at the server.

  • •

    Syncing: after S𝑆S hops, each client combines its model estimates, obtaining 𝜽kt+1=∑γ=1Γwk​γ​𝜽kt,S,Q​(γ)subscriptsuperscript𝜽𝑡1𝑘superscriptsubscript𝛾1Γsubscript𝑤𝑘𝛾subscriptsuperscript𝜽𝑡𝑆𝑄𝑘𝛾\bm{\theta}^{t+1}_{k}=\sum_{\gamma=1}^{\Gamma}w_{k\gamma}\bm{\theta}^{t,S,Q}_{k}(\gamma). We cover the choice of 𝒘k≔(wk​1,…,wk​Γ)≔subscript𝒘𝑘subscript𝑤𝑘1…subscript𝑤𝑘Γ\bm{w}_{k}\coloneqq(w_{k1},\dots,w_{k\Gamma}), which lies in the ΓΓ\Gamma-dimensional probability simplex, later.

Recovering client-server and decentralized setups.

On the one hand, if no client-server communications are available (S→∞→𝑆S\to\infty), our algorithm is reduced to a fully decentralized one, recovering STCD. On the other hand, if the edge set ℰℰ\mathcal{E} is empty, we recover the client-server setting. In this case, if we assign a token to each client (Γ=KΓ𝐾\Gamma=K and each Pγsubscript𝑃𝛾P_{\gamma} has support over a single different client), we get full participation, as in Liu et al. (2022b). In contrast, if Γ<KΓ𝐾\Gamma<K, we recover a partial participation client-server scheme. To the best of our knowledge, this is the first partial participation vertical FL algorithm with multiple local updates.

In general, as we increase the amount of parallel computations (by increasing ΓΓ\Gamma) and client-server communications (by lowering S𝑆S), the communication efficiency and the number of iterations needed to converge both decrease. Given this trade-off, we see that our choice of S𝑆S and ΓΓ\Gamma depends on the application.

Having introduced the general MTCD algorithm, we now go over two particular instances of it, both for semi-decentralized setups, and present convergence guarantees for each.

Setting with a token per cluster.

We now present some convergence guarantees for MTCD in the case where we have C𝐶C disjoint clusters of clients 𝒞1,…,𝒞Csubscript𝒞1…subscript𝒞𝐶\mathcal{C}_{1},\dots,\mathcal{C}_{C} and one token roams each cluster, hence Γ=CΓ𝐶\Gamma=C. Without loss of generality, we assume γ𝛾\gamma roams 𝒞γsubscript𝒞𝛾\mathcal{C}_{\gamma}, allowing us to use γ𝛾\gamma and c𝑐c interchangeably. Thus, Pγsubscript𝑃𝛾P_{\gamma} has support over 𝒞γsubscript𝒞𝛾\mathcal{C}_{\gamma}, and only over 𝒞γsubscript𝒞𝛾\mathcal{C}_{\gamma}. We also define a cluster containing only the server, 𝒞0≔{0}≔subscript𝒞00\mathcal{C}_{0}\coloneqq\{0\}.

These clusters may correspond to the natural topology of the communication graph, due to physical limitations or to privacy constraints preventing communications between clients in different clusters (e.g., households or companies). Yet, we may also generate artificial partitioning of the original graph, prior to learning our model, in order to allow for the use of multiple tokens while avoiding overlapping trajectories, rather than having a single token roaming over a too large (and thus poorly connected) graph.

Since in this setting the blocks of coordinates being updated in each model estimate are disjoint, we let 𝒘k∈ℝΓsubscript𝒘𝑘superscriptℝΓ\bm{w}_{k}\in\mathbb{R}^{\Gamma} be the one-hot encoding for the token that visits client k𝑘k, thus combining the model estimates by simply taking the updated version of each block.

Theorem 1.

Let f𝑓f have a nonempty set of minimizers and let all f​(⋅;𝐁)𝑓⋅𝐁f(\cdot;\bm{B}) be L𝐿L-smooth (A1) and have an unbiased gradient (A2) with a bounded variance (A3). If (𝛉t)superscript𝛉𝑡\left(\bm{\theta}^{t}\right) is a sequence generated by Algorithm 2 with η∈(0,ρ(L+1)​S​Q​(ρ+S​e​(1+e)))𝜂0𝜌𝐿1𝑆𝑄𝜌𝑆𝑒1𝑒\eta\in\left(0,\frac{\rho}{(L+1)SQ(\rho+Se(1+e))}\right) under the token per cluster setting (that is, P𝑃P, 𝒢𝒢\mathcal{G}, and 𝐰ksubscript𝐰𝑘\bm{w}_{k} as explained above) and ℙ​(kγt,0=k)>0ℙsubscriptsuperscript𝑘𝑡0𝛾𝑘0\mathbb{P}(k^{t,0}_{\gamma}=k)>0 for all γ𝛾\gamma and k∈𝒞γ𝑘subscript𝒞𝛾k\in\mathcal{C}_{\gamma}, then:

𝔼​[1T​∑t=0T−1∥∇f​(𝜽t)∥2]=𝒪​(ΔT+σ2B),𝔼delimited-[]1𝑇superscriptsubscript𝑡0𝑇1superscriptdelimited-∥∥∇𝑓superscript𝜽𝑡2𝒪Δ𝑇superscript𝜎2𝐵\mathbb{E}\left[\frac{1}{T}\sum_{t=0}^{T-1}\left\lVert\nabla f\left(\bm{\theta}^{t}\right)\right\rVert^{2}\right]=\mathcal{O}\left(\frac{\Delta}{T}+\frac{\sigma^{2}}{B}\right), (4)

where the expectation is over {kct,s}subscriptsuperscript𝑘𝑡𝑠𝑐\{{k}^{t,s}_{c}\} and {ℬt}subscriptℬ𝑡\{\mathcal{B}_{t}\}. Here, Δ≔f​(𝛉0)−f⋆≔Δ𝑓superscript𝛉0superscript𝑓⋆\Delta\coloneqq f\left(\bm{\theta}^{0}\right)-f^{\star}.

Encouragingly, we see that, for full batch (exact gradient), we recover the 𝒪​(Δ/T)𝒪Δ𝑇\mathcal{O}(\Delta/T) rate of convergence for the (expected) squared norm of the gradient of centralized CD methods. Further, for mini-batches, by choosing a sufficiently large batch size B=Ω​(σ2/ϵ)𝐵Ωsuperscript𝜎2italic-ϵB=\Omega(\sigma^{2}/\epsilon) we can preserve the iteration complexity to reach 𝔼​[1T​∑t=0T−1∥∇f​(𝜽t)∥2]≤ϵ𝔼delimited-[]1𝑇superscriptsubscript𝑡0𝑇1superscriptdelimited-∥∥∇𝑓superscript𝜽𝑡2italic-ϵ\mathbb{E}\left[\frac{1}{T}\sum_{t=0}^{T-1}\left\lVert\nabla f\left(\bm{\theta}^{t}\right)\right\rVert^{2}\right]\leq\epsilon.

Setting with overlapping token trajectories.

We now present some convergence guarantees for MTCD in the setting where we allow for overlapping token trajectories. We propose choosing the convex combination weights to be 𝒘k=(1Γ,…,1Γ)∈ℝΓsubscript𝒘𝑘1Γ…1ΓsuperscriptℝΓ\bm{w}_{k}=(\frac{1}{\Gamma},\dots,\frac{1}{\Gamma})\in\mathbb{R}^{\Gamma} for all k𝑘k, thus combining the model estimates by averaging them. We also consider, for simplicity, that Pγ=Psubscript𝑃𝛾𝑃P_{\gamma}=P, and assume that distribution P𝑃P has support over all clients.

In this setting, to handle the periodic combination by averaging of the model estimates, we develop convergence guarantees for convex objectives. The standard definition of convexity is given below.

Assumption 4 (Convexity).

A function f:ℝd↦ℝ:𝑓maps-tosuperscriptℝ𝑑ℝf\colon\mathbb{R}^{d}\mapsto\mathbb{R} is convex if for all a∈[0,1]𝑎01a\in[0,1]:

f​(a​𝒙+(1−a)​𝒚)≤a​f​(𝒙)+(1−a)​f​(𝒚),∀𝒙,𝒚∈ℝd.formulae-sequence𝑓𝑎𝒙1𝑎𝒚𝑎𝑓𝒙1𝑎𝑓𝒚for-all𝒙𝒚superscriptℝ𝑑f(a\bm{x}+(1-a)\bm{y})\leq af(\bm{x})+(1-a)f(\bm{y}),\quad\forall\;\bm{x},\bm{y}\in\mathbb{R}^{d}. (A4)
Theorem 2.

Let f𝑓f be convex (A4) and have a nonempty set of minimizers and let all f​(⋅;𝐁)𝑓⋅𝐁f(\cdot;\bm{B}) be L𝐿L-smooth (A1) and have an unbiased gradient (A2) with a bounded variance (A3). If (𝛉t)superscript𝛉𝑡\left(\bm{\theta}^{t}\right) is a sequence generated by Algorithm 2 with for η∈(0,ρ′(L+1)​S​Q​(ρ′+S​e​(1+e)))𝜂0superscript𝜌′𝐿1𝑆𝑄superscript𝜌′𝑆𝑒1𝑒\eta\in\left(0,\frac{\rho^{\prime}}{(L+1)SQ(\rho^{\prime}+Se(1+e))}\right) under the overlapping tokens setting (that is, P𝑃P, 𝒢𝒢\mathcal{G}, and 𝐰ksubscript𝐰𝑘\bm{w}_{k} as explained above) and ℙ​(kγt,0=k)>0ℙsubscriptsuperscript𝑘𝑡0𝛾𝑘0\mathbb{P}(k^{t,0}_{\gamma}=k)>0 for all γ∈[Γ]𝛾delimited-[]Γ\gamma\in[\Gamma] and k∈[K]𝑘delimited-[]𝐾k\in[K], then:

𝔼​[1T​∑t=0T−1∥∇f​(𝜽t)∥2]=𝒪​(ΔT+σ2B),𝔼delimited-[]1𝑇superscriptsubscript𝑡0𝑇1superscriptdelimited-∥∥∇𝑓superscript𝜽𝑡2𝒪Δ𝑇superscript𝜎2𝐵\mathbb{E}\left[\frac{1}{T}\sum_{t=0}^{T-1}\left\lVert\nabla f\left(\bm{\theta}^{t}\right)\right\rVert^{2}\right]=\mathcal{O}\left(\frac{\Delta}{T}+\frac{\sigma^{2}}{B}\right),

where the expectation is over {kγt,s}subscriptsuperscript𝑘𝑡𝑠𝛾\{{k}^{t,s}_{\gamma}\} and {ℬt}subscriptℬ𝑡\{\mathcal{B}_{t}\}. Here, Δ≔f​(𝛉0)−f⋆≔Δ𝑓superscript𝛉0superscript𝑓⋆\Delta\coloneqq f\left(\bm{\theta}^{0}\right)-f^{\star}.

As in the token per cluster setting, we recover the 𝒪​(Δ/T)𝒪Δ𝑇\mathcal{O}(\Delta/T) rate for the (expected) squared norm of the gradient when the exact gradient is used, matching the rate of centralized CD methods, and, for a sufficiently large mini-batch size B=Ω​(σ2/ϵ)𝐵Ωsuperscript𝜎2italic-ϵB=\Omega(\sigma^{2}/\epsilon), we preserve the iteration complexity to reach 𝔼​[1T​∑t=0T−1∥∇f​(𝜽t)∥2]≤ϵ𝔼delimited-[]1𝑇superscriptsubscript𝑡0𝑇1superscriptdelimited-∥∥∇𝑓superscript𝜽𝑡2italic-ϵ\mathbb{E}\left[\frac{1}{T}\sum_{t=0}^{T-1}\left\lVert\nabla f\left(\bm{\theta}^{t}\right)\right\rVert^{2}\right]\leq\epsilon.

4 Experiments

We test our method empirically, comparing it to DCPA (Alghunaim et al., 2021), a state-of-the-art fully decentralized method, and a standard vertical FL (S-VFL) method which, since we do not consider compression in our experiments, coincides with both C-VFL (Castiglia et al., 2022) and FedBCD (Liu et al., 2022b). Note that, while some trajectories have a small variance, making the confidence interval hard to see, all experiments are run for 5 seeds.

4.1 Convex problems

In this section, we use CVXPY (Diamond and Boyd, 2016) to obtain f⋆superscript𝑓⋆f^{\star}, to use the (relative) suboptimality gap f​(𝜽t)−f⋆f⋆𝑓superscript𝜽𝑡superscript𝑓⋆superscript𝑓⋆\frac{f(\bm{\theta}^{t})-f^{\star}}{f^{\star}} as a metric. We define iteration as the cumulative number of hops and denote by CC​2​Csubscript𝐶𝐶2𝐶C_{C2C} and CC​2​Ssubscript𝐶𝐶2𝑆C_{C2S} the cost of Client-To-Client and Client-To-Server communications, respectively, whose ratio is important for SDFL. For simplicity, we assume CC​2​Ssubscript𝐶𝐶2𝑆C_{C2S} is the same for communications from the client to the server and vice-versa, although this is often not the case. Throughout Section 4, we consider CC​2​S/CC​2​C=100subscript𝐶𝐶2𝑆subscript𝐶𝐶2𝐶100C_{C2S}/C_{C2C}=100 when plotting the suboptimality gap with respect to the communication cost, multiplying the number of CC​2​Csubscript𝐶𝐶2𝐶C_{C2C} communications by 0.010.010.01 (each communication unit is the size of the token, which varies with the setup) before adding them to the number of C2S communications, to obtain the communication costs. For MTCD, we assume a uniform distribution over the clients when resuming roaming. In Section 4.1, we allow for the tokens to overlap.

We perform ridge regression on a dataset generated following the same process as (Alghunaim et al., 2021), with N=1000𝑁1000N=1000 samples and d=2000𝑑2000d=2000 features split evenly across clients. We have f(𝜽)=∥𝑿𝜽−𝒚∥22/2+α∥𝜽∥22/2f(\bm{\theta})=\left\|\bm{X}\bm{\theta}-\bm{y}\right\rVert_{2}^{2}/2+\alpha\|\bm{\theta}\rVert_{2}^{2}/2, with α=10𝛼10\alpha=10. For this problem, we use η=10−5𝜂superscript105\eta=10^{-5} and Q=20𝑄20Q=20 for MTCD and η=5×10−7𝜂5superscript107\eta=5\times 10^{-7} and Q=20𝑄20Q=20 for S-VFL. For DCPA, we use μw=0.01subscript𝜇𝑤0.01\mu_{w}=0.01, μy=0.0003subscript𝜇𝑦0.0003\mu_{y}=0.0003, and μx=0.03subscript𝜇𝑥0.03\mu_{x}=0.03.

We perform sparse logistic regression on the Gisette dataset (Guyon et al., 2004), where N=6000𝑁6000N=6000 and d=5000𝑑5000d=5000, again split evenly across clients. Let s​(z)≔(1+e−z)−1≔𝑠𝑧superscript1superscript𝑒𝑧1s(z)\coloneqq(1+e^{-z})^{-1} and β=1𝛽1\beta=1:

f(𝜽)=−∑n[ynlogs(𝒙n⊤𝜽)+(1−yn)log(1−s(𝒙n⊤𝜽))]+β∥𝜽∥1,yn∈{0,1},n∈[N].\textstyle{f(\bm{\theta})=-\sum_{n}\left[y_{n}\log s(\bm{x}_{n}^{\top}\bm{\theta})+(1-y_{n})\log(1-s(\bm{x}_{n}^{\top}\bm{\theta}))\right]+\beta\|\bm{\theta}\rVert_{1},\quad y_{n}\in\{0,1\},\,n\in[N].}

where 𝒙nsubscript𝒙𝑛\bm{x}_{n} and ynsubscript𝑦𝑛y_{n} denote samples and labels, respectively. We use η=10−4𝜂superscript104\eta=10^{-4} and Q=30𝑄30Q=30 for MTCD and μw=0.001,μy=0.00003,μx=0.003formulae-sequencesubscript𝜇𝑤0.001formulae-sequencesubscript𝜇𝑦0.00003subscript𝜇𝑥0.003\mu_{w}=0.001,\mu_{y}=0.00003,\mu_{x}=0.003 for DCPA.666In DCPA, the lack of a closed form solution for the proximal operator of the convex conjugate of the logistic regression loss leads to the need to solve a local optimization problem at each client at every iteration.

Fully decentralized setting.

In Figure 3, we see that, while MTCD with S→∞→𝑆S\to\infty and Γ=1Γ1\Gamma=1 (that is, STCD) does not improve upon DCPA in terms of progress per iteration, it is significantly more communication efficient. Yet, STCD is particularly vulnerable to poorly connected networks, as seen when going from an Erdős–Rényi graph to a path graph. Note that, for sparse logistic regression, while the proximal term used to handle the regularizer is not covered by our analysis, it does well empirically. Figure 4 shows additional ridge regression experiments in the N≫dmuch-greater-than𝑁𝑑N\gg d regime across six different graph topologies.

SDFL setting.

We now tackle the same ridge regression problem, now focusing on path graphs, where poor connectivity is a greater challenge. In Figure 5, we see in the top row that our method improves upon the communication efficiency of the other methods. When plotting the number of communications needed to attain a suboptimality gap of 10−4superscript10410^{-4} for each CC​2​C/CC​2​Ssubscript𝐶𝐶2𝐶subscript𝐶𝐶2𝑆C_{C2C}/C_{C2S}, we see that, for different values of CC​2​C/CC​2​Ssubscript𝐶𝐶2𝐶subscript𝐶𝐶2𝑆C_{C2C}/C_{C2S}, the communication efficiency of SDFL methods varies. In the bottom row, we see that, as we increase the syncing frequency, the convergence per iterations speeds up and the communication efficiency decreases, as expected. This illustrates the flexibility of our method, which allows us to choose a regime at which to operate.

4.2 Neural network training

We train an MVCNN (Su et al., 2015) model on ModelNet10 (Wu et al., 2015), a dataset of 3D CAD models. We consider 121212 clients split into two clusters of six clients, each capturing a different (2D) view of each object, and run MTCD for both complete and path graphs with S=6𝑆6S=6. We use a fixed η=0.001𝜂0.001\eta=0.001 for S-VFL. When running MTCD on 2 complete graph clusters with 6 clients each, we also start with η=0.001𝜂0.001\eta=0.001 but halve it every 20 epochs. On the path graph clusters, we start with η=0.0005𝜂0.0005\eta=0.0005 and halve it every 20 epochs. For both both types of graph, we use S=6𝑆6S=6. We use Q=10𝑄10Q=10 and a batch size of 64 for both MTCD and S-VFL.

We also train a ResNet18 (He et al., 2016) on CIFAR-10 (Krizhevsky et al., 2009), for K=4𝐾4K=4 and two clusters (2 clients each). For MTCD, we use S=2𝑆2S=2. We use a fixed η=0.0001𝜂0.0001\eta=0.0001, Q=10𝑄10Q=10 and a batch size of 100 for both S-VFL and MTCD. For MTCD, we use S=2𝑆2S=2.

In Figure 6, we present the results of the ModelNet10 and the CIFAR-10 experiments, both in the token-per-cluster setting. In both, we observe a similar performace in terms of convergence per iteration, but that MTCD outperforms the baseline in communication efficiency.

5 Conclusions

We formalize the multi-token SDFL scheme and propose MTCD, a communication-efficient SDFL algorithm for vertical FL. We provide convergence guarantees for our method and show empirically the improved communication efficiency of our algorithm as well as the power of endowing decentralized methods with periodical client-server communications. A natural extension to this work is to consider compression and privacy mechanisms, such as differential privacy.

Appendix A Preliminaries

If a function is L𝐿L-smooth (A1), then the following quadratic upper bound holds:

f​(𝒚)≤f​(𝒙)+∇f​(𝒙)⊤​(𝒚−𝒙)+L2​∥𝒙−𝒚∥2,∀𝒙,𝒚∈ℝd.formulae-sequence𝑓𝒚𝑓𝒙∇𝑓superscript𝒙top𝒚𝒙𝐿2superscriptdelimited-∥∥𝒙𝒚2for-all𝒙𝒚superscriptℝ𝑑f(\bm{y})\leq f(\bm{x})+\nabla f(\bm{x})^{\top}(\bm{y}-\bm{x})+\frac{L}{2}\lVert\bm{x}-\bm{y}\rVert^{2},\quad\forall\;\bm{x},\bm{y}\in\mathbb{R}^{d}. (5)
Definition 1 (Markov chain).

A sequence of random variables (Zt)t≥0subscriptsuperscript𝑍𝑡𝑡0(Z^{t})_{t\geq 0} is a finite-state space 𝒦𝒦\mathcal{K} Markov chain if, for all i,j∈𝒦𝑖𝑗𝒦\,i,j\in\mathcal{K},

ℙ​(Zt+1=j∣Z0,…,Zt−1,Zt=i)=ℙ​(Zt+1=j∣Zt=i)≕(𝑷​(t))i​j,ℙsuperscript𝑍𝑡1conditional𝑗superscript𝑍0…superscript𝑍𝑡1superscript𝑍𝑡𝑖ℙsuperscript𝑍𝑡1conditional𝑗superscript𝑍𝑡𝑖≕subscript𝑷𝑡𝑖𝑗\mathbb{P}(Z^{t+1}=j\mid Z^{0},\dots,Z^{t-1},Z^{t}=i)=\mathbb{P}(Z^{t+1}=j\mid Z^{t}=i)\eqqcolon(\bm{P}(t))_{ij},

where 𝐏​(t)∈ℝ|𝒦|×|𝒦|𝐏𝑡superscriptℝ𝒦𝒦\bm{P}(t)\in\mathbb{R}^{|\mathcal{K}|\times|\mathcal{K}|} is called the transition matrix. A Markov chain is said to be:

  • •

    time-homogeneous if the transition matrix is constant, that is, 𝑷​(t)=𝑷𝑷𝑡𝑷\bm{P}(t)=\bm{P} for all t𝑡t;

  • •

    irreducible if, starting from any state, all states can be reached eventually, that is, there exists a t𝑡t such that (𝑷t)i​j>0subscriptsuperscript𝑷𝑡𝑖𝑗0(\bm{P}^{t})_{ij}>0 for all i,j∈𝒦𝑖𝑗𝒦\,i,j\in\mathcal{K};

  • •

    aperiodic if gcd​({t≥1:(𝑷t)i​i>0})=1gcdconditional-set𝑡1subscriptsuperscript𝑷𝑡𝑖𝑖01\text{gcd}(\{t\geq 1\colon(\bm{P}^{t})_{ii}>0\})=1 for all states i∈𝒦𝑖𝒦i\in\mathcal{K}, that is, if all states have period 1, where the period of a state i𝑖i is defined as the greatest common divisor of the set of times when it is possible for the Markov chain to return to starting position i𝑖i;

  • •

    reversible if πi​𝑷i​j=πj​𝑷j​isubscript𝜋𝑖subscript𝑷𝑖𝑗subscript𝜋𝑗subscript𝑷𝑗𝑖\pi_{i}\bm{P}_{ij}=\pi_{j}\bm{P}_{ji} for all i,j∈𝒦𝑖𝑗𝒦i,j\in\mathcal{K}, where 𝝅=(π1,…,π|𝒦|)𝝅subscript𝜋1…subscript𝜋𝒦\bm{\pi}=(\pi_{1},\dots,\pi_{|\mathcal{K}|}) is the stationary distribution, which is defined as the distribution satisfying 𝝅⊤=𝝅⊤​𝑷superscript𝝅topsuperscript𝝅top𝑷\bm{\pi}^{\top}=\bm{\pi}^{\top}\bm{P}.

A Markov chain is a lazy random walk (henceforth referred to simply as a random walk) if its states correspond to nodes of a graph and

𝑷i​j={1d​(i)+1if ​j∈𝒩¯i,0otherwise,subscript𝑷𝑖𝑗cases1𝑑𝑖1if 𝑗subscript¯𝒩𝑖0otherwise\bm{P}_{ij}=\begin{cases}\frac{1}{d(i)+1}\quad&\text{if }j\in\bar{\mathcal{N}}_{i},\\ 0&\text{otherwise},\end{cases}

where d​(i)𝑑𝑖d(i) denote the degree of node i𝑖i. A random walk on a static, connected, and undirected graph specifies a finite-state, time-homogeneous, irreducible, and aperiodic Markov chain. If a Markov chain is irreducible and aperiodic, every row of 𝑷tsuperscript𝑷𝑡\bm{P}^{t} will converge to a unique stationary distribution 𝝅𝝅\bm{\pi}, as shown in (Levin and Peres, 2017). We define πmin≔mini⁡πi≔subscript𝜋subscript𝑖subscript𝜋𝑖\pi_{\min}\coloneqq\min_{i}\pi_{i} and denote by dmaxsubscript𝑑d_{\max} and dminsubscript𝑑d_{\min} the maximum and minimum degrees of any node k∈𝒦𝑘𝒦k\in\mathcal{K}, respectively.

Definition 2 (Mixing time).

We say τϵsubscript𝜏italic-ϵ\tau_{\epsilon} is the ϵitalic-ϵ\epsilon-mixing time of a Markov chain if

τϵ≔min⁡{t:supi∈𝒦dT​V​((𝑷t)i:,𝝅)≤ϵ},≔subscript𝜏italic-ϵ:𝑡subscriptsupremum𝑖𝒦subscript𝑑𝑇𝑉subscriptsuperscript𝑷𝑡:𝑖absent𝝅italic-ϵ\tau_{\epsilon}\coloneqq\min\left\{t\colon\sup_{i\in\mathcal{K}}\,d_{TV}\left(\left(\bm{P}^{t}\right)_{i:},\bm{\pi}\right)\leq\epsilon\right\},

where dT​Vsubscript𝑑𝑇𝑉d_{TV} is the total variation distance. For countable sets, our case, dT​V​(𝐱,𝐲)=∥𝐱−𝐲∥1/2subscript𝑑𝑇𝑉𝐱𝐲subscriptdelimited-∥∥𝐱𝐲12d_{TV}(\bm{x},\bm{y})=\lVert\bm{x}-\bm{y}\rVert_{1}/2.

We use the following result in our analysis.

Remark (Grönwall-Bellman lemma).

Let a,b≥0𝑎𝑏0a,b\geq 0 be constants, if sequence (un)n=0Nsuperscriptsubscriptsubscript𝑢𝑛𝑛0𝑁(u_{n})_{n=0}^{N} satisfies

un≤a+b​∑i=0n−1ui,0≤n≤N,thenun≤a​(1+b)n,0≤n≤N.formulae-sequenceformulae-sequencesubscript𝑢𝑛𝑎𝑏superscriptsubscript𝑖0𝑛1subscript𝑢𝑖0𝑛𝑁thensubscript𝑢𝑛𝑎superscript1𝑏𝑛0𝑛𝑁u_{n}\leq a+b\sum_{i=0}^{n-1}u_{i},\quad 0\leq n\leq N,\qquad\text{then}\qquad u_{n}\leq a(1+b)^{n},\quad 0\leq n\leq N. (6)
Proof.

The n=0𝑛0n=0 base case is trivial. For the induction step, we assume the result we want to show holds for 0≤n≤k−10𝑛𝑘10\leq n\leq k-1 and notice that:

uk≤a+b​∑i=0k−1ui≤a+b​∑i=0k−1a​(1+b)i=a​(1+b​∑i=0k−1(1+b)i)≤(a)a​(1+b)k,subscript𝑢𝑘𝑎𝑏superscriptsubscript𝑖0𝑘1subscript𝑢𝑖𝑎𝑏superscriptsubscript𝑖0𝑘1𝑎superscript1𝑏𝑖𝑎1𝑏superscriptsubscript𝑖0𝑘1superscript1𝑏𝑖superscript𝑎𝑎superscript1𝑏𝑘u_{k}\leq a+b\sum_{i=0}^{k-1}u_{i}\leq a+b\sum_{i=0}^{k-1}a(1+b)^{i}=a\left(1+b\sum_{i=0}^{k-1}(1+b)^{i}\right)\stackrel{{\scriptstyle(a)}}{{\leq}}a(1+b)^{k},

where in (a)𝑎(a) we use the finite sum of a geometric series, which is equal to the expression that follows for the case b>0𝑏0b>0 and, to handle b=0𝑏0b=0, we can use Bernoulli’s inequality. ∎

Consider the set of vectors {𝒂1,…,𝒂n}subscript𝒂1…subscript𝒂𝑛\{\bm{a}_{1},\dots,\bm{a}_{n}\}, using the Cauchy–Schwarz inequality we have that:

∥∑i=1n𝒂i∥2≤n​∑i=1n∥𝒂i∥2.superscriptdelimited-∥∥superscriptsubscript𝑖1𝑛subscript𝒂𝑖2𝑛superscriptsubscript𝑖1𝑛superscriptdelimited-∥∥subscript𝒂𝑖2\left\lVert\sum_{i=1}^{n}\bm{a}_{i}\right\rVert^{2}\leq n\sum_{i=1}^{n}\left\lVert\bm{a}_{i}\right\rVert^{2}. (7)

Appendix B Token roaming lemmas

Lemmas 1, 2, and 3 concern token roaming. Yet, for clarity, we abstract away the tokens and communications, studying a setup-agnostic Markov chain coordinate descent instead, summarized in Algorithm 3. We consider ψ:ℝd′→ℝ:𝜓→superscriptℝsuperscript𝑑′ℝ\psi\colon\mathbb{R}^{d^{\prime}}\to\mathbb{R}, a partitioning of [d′]delimited-[]superscript𝑑′[d^{\prime}] with blocks k∈𝒦𝑘𝒦k\in\mathcal{K}, and let ∇¯k​ψ​(𝒗)∈ℝd′subscript¯∇𝑘𝜓𝒗superscriptℝsuperscript𝑑′\bar{\nabla}_{k}\psi\left(\bm{v}\right)\in\mathbb{R}^{d^{\prime}} denote a vector whose block k𝑘k corresponds to ∇kψ​(𝒗)subscript∇𝑘𝜓𝒗\nabla_{k}\psi\left(\bm{v}\right) and all other entries are zeros. Note that kisuperscript𝑘𝑖k^{i} is fixed for i=0𝑖0i=0 and a random variable for i∈[S]𝑖delimited-[]𝑆i\in[S]. We further define the surrogate offset as 𝜹i,j≔∇¯ki​ψ​(𝒗i,j)−∇ψ​(𝒗0,0)≔superscript𝜹𝑖𝑗subscript¯∇superscript𝑘𝑖𝜓superscript𝒗𝑖𝑗∇𝜓superscript𝒗00\bm{\delta}^{i,j}\coloneqq\bar{\nabla}_{k^{i}}\psi\left(\bm{v}^{i,j}\right)-\nabla\psi\left(\bm{v}^{0,0}\right). As mentioned in the paper, token roaming is closely related to (Sun et al., 2019), yet our analysis differs significantly, since the results in (Sun et al., 2019) require S→∞→𝑆S\to\infty and our end goal is to study the convergence of MTCD with respect to syncing steps, for a finite number of hops S𝑆S.

Lemma 2.

If (𝐯s,q)superscript𝐯𝑠𝑞\left(\bm{v}^{s,q}\right) is a sequence generated by Algorithm 3 and ℙ​(kS=k)>0ℙsuperscript𝑘𝑆𝑘0\mathbb{P}(k^{S}=k)>0 for all k𝑘k, then:

where the expectation is taken over {ks}s=1Ssubscriptsuperscriptsuperscript𝑘𝑠𝑆𝑠1\{k^{s}\}^{S}_{s=1} and ℙ​(kS=k)≥ρ>0ℙsuperscript𝑘𝑆𝑘𝜌0\mathbb{P}(k^{S}=k)\geq\rho>0 for all k𝑘k. We can obtain different lower bounds on ρ𝜌\rho depending on the assumptions we make:

  • •

    If 𝑷𝑷\bm{P} is a lazy random walk on a graph, then ρ≥(1/(dmax+1))S𝜌superscript1subscript𝑑1𝑆\rho\geq(1/(d_{\max}+1))^{S};

  • •

    If the graph is static, connected, and undirected and S≥3​log⁡(2​|ℰ|/(dmin+1))2​λ𝑆32ℰsubscript𝑑12𝜆S\geq\frac{3\log(2|\mathcal{E}|/(d_{\min}+1))}{2\lambda}, where λ≔1−λ2∈(0,1)≔𝜆1subscript𝜆201\lambda\coloneqq 1-\lambda_{2}\in(0,1), with λ2subscript𝜆2\lambda_{2} denoting the second largest eigenvalue of 𝑷𝑷\bm{P} in absolute value, then ρ≥dmin+14​|ℰ|𝜌subscript𝑑14ℰ\rho\geq\frac{d_{\min}+1}{4|\mathcal{E}|}.

While ℙ​(kS=k)>0ℙsuperscript𝑘𝑆𝑘0\mathbb{P}(k^{S}=k)>0 is an assumption needed for Lemma 2, it brings no loss of generality for the theorems where Lemma 2 is used, where this property always holds. This will become clear when we prove the theorems.

Proof.

Let ∑s,qsubscript𝑠𝑞\sum_{s,q} denote ∑s=0S∑q=0Q−1subscriptsuperscript𝑆𝑠0superscriptsubscript𝑞0𝑄1\sum^{S}_{s=0}\sum_{q=0}^{Q-1}, we have that

and, using the fact that ∥∇kψ​(𝒗0,0)∥2≥0superscriptdelimited-∥∥subscript∇𝑘𝜓superscript𝒗0020\left\lVert\nabla_{k}\psi\left(\bm{v}^{0,0}\right)\right\rVert^{2}\geq 0, we get:

∑k∈𝒦Q​∑sℙ​(ks=k)​∥∇kψ​(𝒗0,0)∥2≥∑k∈𝒦Q​ℙ​(kS=k)​∥∇kψ​(𝒗0,0)∥2.subscript𝑘𝒦𝑄subscript𝑠ℙsuperscript𝑘𝑠𝑘superscriptdelimited-∥∥subscript∇𝑘𝜓superscript𝒗002subscript𝑘𝒦𝑄ℙsuperscript𝑘𝑆𝑘superscriptdelimited-∥∥subscript∇𝑘𝜓superscript𝒗002\displaystyle\sum_{k\in\mathcal{K}}Q\sum_{s}\mathbb{P}(k^{s}=k)\left\lVert\nabla_{k}\psi\left(\bm{v}^{0,0}\right)\right\rVert^{2}\geq\sum_{k\in\mathcal{K}}Q\mathbb{P}(k^{S}=k)\left\lVert\nabla_{k}\psi\left(\bm{v}^{0,0}\right)\right\rVert^{2}.

We now obtain two different lower bounds on ℙ​(kS=k)ℙsuperscript𝑘𝑆𝑘\mathbb{P}(k^{S}=k), for different sets of assumptions:

  • •

    If 𝑷𝑷\bm{P} is a lazy random walk on a graph, ρ≥(1/dmax+1)S𝜌superscript1subscript𝑑1𝑆\rho\geq(1/d_{\max}+1)^{S} follows directly from the assumption that ℙ​(kS=k)>0ℙsuperscript𝑘𝑆𝑘0\mathbb{P}(k^{S}=k)>0 and the transition probabilities of the random walk:

    ℙ​(kS)=∑k1,…,kS−2[∏i=0S−2ℙ​(ki+1∣ki)]≥0⟹ℙ​(kS=k)≥(1dmax+1)S;ℙsuperscript𝑘𝑆subscriptsuperscript𝑘1…superscript𝑘𝑆2delimited-[]superscriptsubscriptproduct𝑖0𝑆2ℙconditionalsuperscript𝑘𝑖1superscript𝑘𝑖0ℙsuperscript𝑘𝑆𝑘superscript1subscript𝑑1𝑆\mathbb{P}(k^{S})=\sum_{k^{1},\dots,k^{S-2}}\left[\prod_{i=0}^{S-2}\mathbb{P}(k^{i+1}\mid k^{i})\right]\geq 0\implies\mathbb{P}(k^{S}=k)\geq\left(\frac{1}{d_{\max}+1}\right)^{S};
  • •

    To avoid an exponential dependency on S𝑆S we can further assume that the graph is static, connected, and undirected,777Similar bounds can be found for more general graphs, but we focus on this case for simplicity. and that S≥τ𝑆𝜏S\geq\tau, where τ𝜏\tau is the πmin2subscript𝜋2\frac{\pi_{\min}}{2}-mixing time. It follows from the definition of mixing time (Definition 2) that |(𝑷S)i​j−πj|≤πminsubscriptsuperscript𝑷𝑆𝑖𝑗subscript𝜋𝑗subscript𝜋\lvert\left(\bm{P}^{S}\right)_{ij}-\pi_{j}\rvert\leq\pi_{\min} for all i,j𝑖𝑗i,j and therefore (𝑷S)i​j≥πmin2subscriptsuperscript𝑷𝑆𝑖𝑗subscript𝜋2\left(\bm{P}^{S}\right)_{ij}\geq\frac{\pi_{\min}}{2}. (If (𝑷S)i​j<πmin2subscriptsuperscript𝑷𝑆𝑖𝑗subscript𝜋2\left(\bm{P}^{S}\right)_{ij}<\frac{\pi_{\min}}{2}, then πmin−(𝑷S)i​j>πmin2subscript𝜋subscriptsuperscript𝑷𝑆𝑖𝑗subscript𝜋2\pi_{\min}-\left(\bm{P}^{S}\right)_{ij}>\frac{\pi_{\min}}{2}, contradicting the definition of πmin2subscript𝜋2\frac{\pi_{\min}}{2}-mixing time.) We can now easily verify that, for a random walk, 𝝅=(d​(k)+12​|ℰ|)k∈𝒱𝝅subscript𝑑𝑘12ℰ𝑘𝒱\bm{\pi}=\left(\frac{d(k)+1}{2|\mathcal{E}|}\right)_{k\in\mathcal{V}}, and thus:

    (𝑷S)k0​k≥dmin+14​|ℰ|.subscriptsuperscript𝑷𝑆superscript𝑘0𝑘subscript𝑑14ℰ\left(\bm{P}^{S}\right)_{k^{0}k}\geq\frac{d_{\min}+1}{4|\mathcal{E}|}.

    We now want to upper bound τ𝜏\tau with respect to properties of 𝑷𝑷\bm{P}, to know for what values of S𝑆S this bound holds. For a reversible, aperiodic, and irreducible Markov chain, our case, we have (Paulin, 2015, Proposition 3.3):

    τ≤3​log⁡(1/πmin)2​λ=3​log⁡(2​|ℰ|/(dmin+1))2​λ.𝜏31subscript𝜋2𝜆32ℰsubscript𝑑12𝜆\tau\leq\frac{3\log(1/\pi_{\min})}{2\lambda}=\frac{3\log(2|\mathcal{E}|/(d_{\min}+1))}{2\lambda}.

We now use one of these bounds on ρ𝜌\rho and the fact that ∑k∈𝒦∥∇kψ​(𝒗)∥2=∥∇ψ​(𝒗)∥2subscript𝑘𝒦superscriptdelimited-∥∥subscript∇𝑘𝜓𝒗2superscriptdelimited-∥∥∇𝜓𝒗2\sum_{k\in\mathcal{K}}\left\lVert\nabla_{k}\psi\left(\bm{v}\right)\right\rVert^{2}=\left\lVert\nabla\psi\left(\bm{v}\right)\right\rVert^{2} to arrive at (9). ∎

Note that, in the special case of a random walk on complete graph we have ℙ​(ks=k)=1/|𝒦|ℙsuperscript𝑘𝑠𝑘1𝒦\mathbb{P}(k^{s}=k)=1/\lvert\mathcal{K}\rvert for all k𝑘k, allowing us to avoid the inequalities above altogether and get:

Appendix C Proof of Theorem 1

For the sake of clarity and simplicity, we now consider a setup-agnostic stochastic disjoint parallel Markov chain coordinate descent, presented in Algorithm 4, which abstracts away the tokens and communications of MTCD while remaining mathematically equivalent. Map ℳℳ\mathcal{M} is as defined in Algorithm 3.

In this setup, only block 𝜽𝒞γ​(γ)subscript𝜽subscript𝒞𝛾𝛾\bm{\theta}_{\mathcal{C}_{\gamma}}(\gamma) of 𝜽​(γ)𝜽𝛾\bm{\theta}(\gamma) is updated during the roaming step. Since 𝒞1,…,𝒞Γsubscript𝒞1…subscript𝒞Γ\mathcal{C}_{1},\dots,\mathcal{C}_{\Gamma} are disjoint, no coordinate is updated simultaneously for different model estimates. This allows us to use the simpler notation 𝜽=(𝜽𝒞1​(1),…,𝜽𝒞Γ​(Γ))𝜽subscript𝜽subscript𝒞11…subscript𝜽subscript𝒞ΓΓ\bm{\theta}=(\bm{\theta}_{\mathcal{C}_{1}}(1),\dots,\bm{\theta}_{\mathcal{C}_{\Gamma}}(\Gamma)), focusing on the blocks of 𝜽​(1),…,𝜽​(Γ)𝜽1…𝜽Γ\bm{\theta}(1),\dots,\bm{\theta}(\Gamma) which are updated during the roaming step and seeing their concatenation as a single model estimate.

𝔼​[1T​∑t=0T−1∥∇f​(𝜽t)∥2]≤C4​ΔT+C4​σ22​B.𝔼delimited-[]1𝑇superscriptsubscript𝑡0𝑇1superscriptdelimited-∥∥∇𝑓superscript𝜽𝑡2subscript𝐶4Δ𝑇subscript𝐶4superscript𝜎22𝐵\mathbb{E}\left[\frac{1}{T}\sum_{t=0}^{T-1}\left\lVert\nabla f\left(\bm{\theta}^{t}\right)\right\rVert^{2}\right]\leq\frac{C_{4}\Delta}{T}+\frac{C_{4}\sigma^{2}}{2B}.

∎

Appendix D Proof of Theorem 2

For the sake of clarity and simplicity, we again consider a setup-agnostic version of our method which abstracts away the tokens and communications of MTCD while remaining mathematically equivalent. A stochastic parallel Markov chain coordinate descent where we allow for overlapping blocks of coordinates to be updated simultaneously is presented in Algorithm 5.
